text: The title of this autobiography tells it all "Extreme". If you want to go on a wild ride then this is the book for you. Prepare yourself for some bizarre escapades and foul language and you won't be able to put this book down. Hard to believe anyone could survive a life such as this.

Excellent. I read A LOT of bios- especially rock and celebrity... but I never read one that I connected with so personally, or was so sad to finish. I just want to have coffee with Sharon every morning.... in another life, perhaps.Painfully honest about her struggle as the wife of an addict. I am the wife of an alcoholic, and I have read a lot of books about addiction and/or addicts. But none other has touched my heart so deeply. If you love an addict- spouse, child, friend, etc- and have found other accounts to not exactly portray your pov, try this one. I am a similar smart-ass, no-back-down personality to Sharon, I think. But I often feel others think my commitment to my husband is viewed as a weakness. Like, if I was so tough, I would "just leave".... this aspect of living with an addict is a central theme of Sharon's book. So also is the guilt brought on by considering cutting lose someone who has a real disease, when all of your own success was built on their back.But, dont get me wrong-- this is NOT a whiny wallowing version of being an addicts wife. It is an account of owning your part, and remaining faithful, while maintaining to the end a position of fighting for an addict until they are either in remission or gone. I may some day see my husband finish himself off... but it wont be without me fighting him every step of the way...It was also a story of hope, in that- at the time of it's finish- Ozzy was 2 years clean, and her son 3 years. Sharon's story reinforced my belief that my way may not be the AlAnon way, but it is MY journey... not conducive to the choices of others, but not "wrong" either.

I must admit I expected a lot more from Sharon Osbourne, being the strong opionated woman that she is. Instead I discovered a woman very much dependant and dictated to by those around her, particularly her father (who was not a nice chap to put it nicely) then by her partners and husband. I was shocked to discover that the woman we know today did not come out until she was nearly killed by the man she had married and to whom she stood by despite his abusive nature. Putting that aside I was also surprised by how little Sharon actually gave of herself to the book, keeping it focused on the acts she grew up around, toured with, managed etc rather than looking into the more personal aspects of her life, such as her personal relationship with her parents (rather than the business one) and how this impacted her decisions in later life. It was not until she has been diagnosed with colon cancer and Ozzy has calmed down dramatically that I began to feel that it was the real Sharon talking rather than a show-biz drama queen. This is an interesting book , particularly if celebrity is your thing but don't expect heart-felt explorations into her past or details of her as a person rather than as a music agent/manager.
It's only $2.99!!!!!I hear this memoir is cray cray

Sharon Osbourne, wife of Ozzy Osbourne of Black Sabbath & bat-eating fame, mother of three, and former talk show host, has a fascinating life to an outsider. That being said, it’s not very fun to read about. Extreme: My Autobiography is chock-full of people who abuse substances, are abusive, and are abused. And most of the people found herein do all three to an extent that I couldn’t find a reason for reading about them.I had high hopes for Osbourne’s book, because I think she is a very likable, strong woman who has accomplished many things. I was disappointed.

I've needed a little bit of Sharon Osbourne in my life! This book really taught me that despite set backs (and Shaz had some major setbacks...is setbacks even the right word for what happened to her?!) it's possible to be a huge success. I'm in awe of someone who clearly has it all: loving husband, amazing career, doting children, and sweet puppies. It was fun to read this after reading Ozzy's autobiography and "compare" notes. A survivor story in more ways than one. HIGHLY recommended.

this review first appeared on [http://intraspace.blogspot.com]anna got this from her book club, i think. i came across it when i was looking for something a bit lighter to read...i suppose it's a bit of a "girl's book", but it's also a rather interesting insight on the music industry of the 50s, 60s, 70s and 80s.sharon osbourne is famous to most people for being the wife of ozzy osbourne, former lead singer of black sabbath. but apart from this significant accomplishment, she was also on the inner circle of the british music industry.her father was an artist manager, and was responsible for bringing rock n roll to britain. he turned down management of a new band called "the beatles" because he thought the idea of british rock was a joke. instead he continued to focus on bringing american acts like chuck berry over to the uk. other famous artists he represented included ELO in the 70s (by then he had caught on to the idea of british music).sharon became involved in the industry, and much of this book is about the corruption and criminal under-current of the music business. nothing girly about that! sharon herself was (is) a bit of a hard woman - not afraid (it transpires) to use her excrement (literally), her language and her fists to prove a point. before i leave off talking about the music industry bits of the book, i should also say - did you know that sharon once managed the smashing pumpkins? she ditched them because billy corgan was a royal pain in the arse.the rest of the book is about her relationship with ozzy - enduring weekly beatings and his insane drug and alcohol addiction. she also talks about her kids and her fight with cancer.so lots of aspects to this book - well worth reading for either the music industry stuff or for the human drama.

I will be honest and admitt the only reason I ended up reading this book, was because I was on holiday and read all my books before it was time to go (truely hate it when that happens) so I tried one of my friends ... well I can say I asctually loooved it! .. I had no idea the live Sharon Osbourne lead prior/during her earlier life with hubby Ozzy!It's a truely remarkable story, one at times seems fictional, but definatly a good read, to look into the life of others and find just how different people's lives are. I think one of the reasons I liked the book so much was due to the amount of honesty layed out on the pages; it makes you feel a certain way when you read it .. All I can say is for me it was a good read,(I don't no maybe it was the extreme heat-but I enjoyed it)I wont spoil anything for anyone wondering about the events that occure inside the book; all I will say is there has been a lot of drama in Sharon Osbourne's life.

Everyone talks about Mrs. Osbourne as a hero but after reading this book I see her as a victim of serious abuse who is incapable to break the abusive circle she has forced herself and her kids to live in. She is a sad example of a woman who keeps staying together with a man who abuses her physically and mentally and tries even to murder her. I don´t see anything heroic in that and definitely wouldn´t count her as a role model. She is an incredible talented and smart woman, so why does she spend her entire life of being a co-dependant for a violent drug user?Also, the style of the book was quite shallow. Osbourne gets by huge happenings in her life in 1-2 sentences. That might of course be because her life is so full of dramatic turns that they wouldn´t fit in abook though it had 5000 pages.If you´re interested to know how functional the Osbourne family truly is I´d recommend a documentary God Bless Ozzy Osbourne,co-produced by Jack Osbourne.

I'm afraid I've never had any respect for Ozzy Osbourne due to the infamous bat and dove incidents, so it's with a great deal of surprise that I have to admit I really enjoyed this book. (Same as I actually enjoyed "The Osbourne's" despite not wanting to...)But I don't know why exactly? After all it's filled with alcoholism, drug addiction, abusive men and above all a very abusive main relationship between Ozzy and Sharon. It's hard for me to see how they have risen above that to have the relationship they seemingly have now. I think I would find it near impossible to love someone who constantly cheated on me, punched and hit me, broke my teeth and of course tried to strangle me to death! Maybe it works because they are as bad as each other!Still I did enjoy it, found it a book I couldn't put down and ended up giving a 4 star rating to...go figure....

I have always thought Sharon Osbourne was an interesting person. Now, after reading her book, it is confirmed. She is an amazing person. Her life was nothing short of an adventure. Her father was a manager in the music industry out of the UK. He was not the ideal father. He was a scammer, a cheat, a mobster and he used Sharon so he could run his crooked business under the radar. Her mother was not any better. Even though her husband cheated on her and treated her worse than a 2-bit whore, she defended him over Sharon several times throughout her life. I didn’t realize how experienced Sharon is in the music business. She meets Ozzy when she was in her early 20’s. They become great friends. They become romantically involved when he is still married. It’s a rocky road, but Ozzy does eventually divorce his wife and marry Sharon. Sharon talks a lot about Ozzy’s addictions and the violence that ensues. She is very open and honest in her writing. I admire her for that. A few things that stand out in my mind after reading this book. Sharon and her family must have lived in 50 different. I swear they are moving to a new house in every chapter. They bounce between LA and England. Sharon gets robbed. Not just once but SEVERAL times. You would think they would learn and get an alarm system or safes or something. Sharon has spunk and seems like a fun person to be around. I enjoyed this book and I’m glad I read it

I like baudy women like Sharon Osbourne, but it was a huge bummer reading about Ozzy constantly cheating on and beating her. I'm glad their relationship "stabelized" and that they've stayed together so long (well, kind of), but it was a laborious read. And I got tired of her sending boxes of excrement to people. Once, maybe in an extreme situation, but it's the sort of trick that gets hackneyed quick.

Oh dear. I really liked Sharon before I read this. But.....they really need to take some personal responsibility! Aggressive, rude, violent, unprofessional and far far too full of her own self importance and whats with all the pissing herself? TMI ! and as for deliberately shitting in peoples shoes and on ornaments and getting her kids to shit on letters in their potty???? REALLYYY?????? Very disappointed.

Before reading this book I thought their reputations had to be exaggerated. They aren't. Sharon and Ozzy are two crazy people. I didn't know about Sharon's family background in the industry, and that was interesting, but, man, everyone in their lives is so dysfunctional. The drama is intriguing, but exhausting.

I always wondered how she could be married to Ozzy, she always seemed like the stable one. Boy, she's was raised with a dysfunctional family. I really have much respect for Sharon and how hard she worked to make Ozzy's career what it was. In a lot of ways her back ground reminds me of my own mother. I love her honesty. You can tell how much she loves her kids and Ozzy.

Wow-a wild and crazy ride through a wild and crazy life. From birth to 50...father Don Arden, a rock promoter, mother a self-absorbed cold fish, meeting Ozzy, life with Ozzy: O.M.G.!!!!!, kids born, dozens of houses, tours, cancer. She's a mama grizzly! He's been a test (slight understatement)--drugs, booze, eccentric. A great read!
A very interesting story that I really enjoyed. Recommended.
Audiobook. I have always liked the Osbournes and enjoyed this, especially as it is read by the author. Very much appreciate the rawness and emotion with which it was read.

“Memory is a strange thing, and since starting this book I have discovered that people’s memories of the same event can be very, very different.”Tell me about it, Sharon. In fact, it’s something I am increasingly finding in these ghost-written celeb tomes. That, in some way, the celebrities are forced to put their own side of versions, albeit ghostwritten (in this case by Penelope Dening, who surprisingly gets a mention on the title page with her subject), to somehow justify where they feel their actions and their character have been scrutinised in the past.None more it seems has this been the case, it seems, but with Sharon Osbourne. TV Star, Mother, Wife to Rock God and a large number of shit excreting small dogs.It should go on record that despite what I might say, the book became the biggest selling British autobiography ever upon release and the most successful female biography upon release when it topped 2 million sales (621,000 of that was in hardback), which is a huge acheivement for the wife of a rock star, currently fading in terms of the chart success he has had in the past. Granted, the very fact that Sharon was not only a judge in possibly one of the most successful shows on TV currently, but the promotional budget behind this title and the avenues of opportunity already out there in terms of her exposure could have done nothing but aid her in this milestone display of selling.Now, let it be said that I firmly believe that not only is Ozzy and Black Sabbath one of the most underrated acts in British music but that Ozzy himself is one of the least talked about successes in terms of that all important industry white elephant, “Cracking America”, with his hugely successful solo career (something unheard of at the time) and what then eventually Ozzfest, a no-nonsense hard rock alternative to the more avant-garde Lollapalooza at the time. But back to Sharon. Mrs. Osbourne (nee Arden) is the daughter of the legendary concert promoter, Don Arden and the relationship between her and her father, not to mention a quite unique and turbulent business partnership, despite her young age. Sharon is nothing but adamant about how she was manipulated as early as in her teens to basically sign her life away on behalf of her father in her business dealings. This has made her not only quite hard and surly but also majorly beligerent and callous towards anyone she takes a disliking to. She has learnt over the years to fight her corner and had her Fuck You, punk spririt firmly established and instilled within her a number of years before the Pistols first rose up from their squats and tread the boards.As early as the Sixties, she was making the sort of important industry decisions that people have spent years in the process of making their way upto in these days. Sharon puts this down to a question of experience and woe be tide any cocky shits in the industry today that try to cross or fuck with her.I, on the other hand, clearly believe that Sharon has got to where she is today through what was essentially a life of priviledge through her father, despite her protestations at the amount of work she has done to add to his legend. The constant naievity of the younger business woman, even well into her thirties is very frustrating and annoying, especially how it has affected her family and her relationship with her husband. A man with his own personal demons and struggles with addiction.In her defence though, she is an absolute rock for Ozzy. As is he for her. Through his rehabilitation and her own battles with colon cancer. The couple have the most passionate and clearly loving relationship that most I’m sure are envious of, that is evident to anyone who even watches an episode of that other surprise success in their lives, their famous MTV reality show, which has made huge stars of Sharon and both children in the programme, Kelly and Jack. It is true that Kelly has not been as successful as first thought, but then why on earth any member of that family would want to follow such an icon as her father into music, I do not know. What I love about Sharon is her attitude and that she doesn’t give a flying fuck. This is admirable and useful no doubt for the business that she is in, but her constant violent and rude nature has damaged her reputation in the public eye. She has been widly criticized for her actions and behaviour as a judge on all seasons of The X Factor, even though I do agree about the guy that won the first season. But then I think everyone realised that you would not have heard of him after the show came to an end. But then The X-Factor has failed to produce anything of either the success or standard as Simon Cowell’s other baby, American Idol.To my dismay, this book was majorly lacking in any ending. To say it was half arsed, would be fair. I really slacked towards the end, despite what I thought would be a great read for me, considering who Sharon is. But I really got a bit sick of Sharon’s constant self-justification and volitile nature. This made it hard for me to actually get to the end of what seems to be a very jumbled and patchy account of events towards the end.It it a very aggressive tome. There is a history of violence and abuse from both sides of the relationship and as heartbreaking as it is, there are interjections of wit and humour along the way. It is quite hard reading though in terms of the arguementative tone of most of the book.I wonder how those two million buyers felt at the end.
Had to read as a part of our trashy book club. She’s lived a life, I’ll give her that.

I really enjoy hearing about someone’s life by that person. This book was so extreme in the things she has gone through. Some things I think I would never put up with and some things I can’t say that, not having been brought up in the same home, with the same people in my life. Overall, I appreciated hearing her story and realizing, yet again, that what the media tells us about people is not the whole story. *if you do not want to hear language, do NOT listen to this book.

Some easy literature this week to give my brain a little bit of rest after the last few weeks of "serious" novels. Sharon Osbourne's Extreme: My Autobiography is good regardless of anyone's expectations. I know that most people don't think much of this loud-mouthed woman, but after all the stories I've heard I became quite interested in her life. We all now those stories about Ozzy biting the head of a bat and Ozzy almost killing Sharon. Granted, most of these stories are related to Ozzy so maybe I should have started with his Autobiography. However, a view from a third party is quite refreshing. Although Sharon's book peeked my interest in this bizarre family, so I might keep on reading.It's hard to describe in this short blog what Sharon Osbourne has been through throughout her life. I don't understand how someone can be so strong when writing about Ozzy and her violent relationship, her horrible bond with her father, cancer, numerous burglaries and lies from people who she thought she was close to. The story about Randy Rhoads almost made me cry and a second later some passages make me laugh. Reading this book is like riding a rollercoaster. It's thrilling and exciting with a few stops and sad moments when it's already over too soon. All I can say at the end is that I'm genuinely happy that her life has worked out the way it has, after all her misfortunes she seems perfectly happy. Good for her!

This was really interesting, and definitely actually written by Sharon Osbourne. If there was a ghost writer involved, it was a great one, because her voice comes through loud and clear and the book's incredibly engaging. Her childhood was really fascinating, and although I knew that she was Ozzy's manager, I didn't understand how deep in that business she had been, or how insane her family was. I also didn't realize that their marriage was so abusive (she goes out of her way to say that she was part of the problem, but her poor coping skills -- throwing things when she gets mad, for example -- don't really exist on the same plane as him trying to choke her to death or punching her in the head whenever he remembers she threw a party without asking him first). She is much, much more forgiving than I would want anyone I cared about to be, both to Ozzy for his abuse/cheating/drugging/drinking, and to her father, who threatened her and her children's lives, stole from her, trashed her to her husband and the press, and yet she takes responsibility for his welfare when he gets old.Quick read, and as celeb memoirs go, one of the more interesting, informative, and candid ones I've read.

I LOVE THIS WOMAN. SHE IS A STRONG, SMART BUSINESS LADY. SHE'S HAD AN INTERESTING LIFE GROWING UP AROUND THE MUSIC BUSINESS LEARNING FROM HER DEMANDING, SHORT TEMPERED FATHER. SHARON HAS WORKED & MANAGED MANY BANDS IN HER LIFE AND ALSO BEST KNOWN TO MANAGING & MARRYING THE GODFATHER OF METAL OZZY. A FULL TIME JOB SHARON HAD MANAGING OZZY WHO WAS USUALLY ALWAYS WASTED OR DRUGED UP MOST OF HIS EARLY CAREER IN MUSIC. SHE LITTERLY HAD TO BABYSIT HIS BAD BEHAVING OF DRUGS, BOOZE AND WOMAN. HAVING TO DEAL WITH HER DEMANDING FATHER & OZZY'S MENTAL & SUBSTANCE ABUSE SHE BECAME THAT HARD DRIVEN BUSINESS WOMAN THAT SHE IS TODAY. SHARON IS BEST KNOWN FOR BEING THE BEST MUSIC MANAGER IN THE BUSINESS FOR MANY BANDS, OZZFEST AND ALSO BEING A FULL TIME MOTHER TO HER THREE KIDS. WITH REALITY TV SHOWS ON HER RESUME SHE AND OZZY ARE STILL TOGETHER HAPPILY MARRIED AND SHE STILL SEEMS TO ENJOY TAKING CARE HER OLDER & MORE RESPONSIBLE OZZY, SHE'S HAD LIVED AN INTERESTING LIFE GOOD AND BAD.

Thanks to this book, I've got Ozzy's first album playing in my car (forgetten how good it was) and I'm ictching to watch 'The Osbournes' again. Luckly I have both seasons on dvd so I'll be doing that very soon. I didn't know who Sharon Osbourne was before I started watching the Osbournes. I already owned albums by Ozzy and Black Sabbath, so Ozzy was the main reason for watching. And like most people I fell in love with the whole family. And I love Sharon! She is the backbone behind all of them. But I didn't relise how much until I read this book. I knew she was Ozzy's manager but I didn't know anything about her past. How awful her parents were. How she had always been in the music business. I love how she always speaks her mind. Didn't expect so much pissing and shitting to be done in the book though lol. A really enjoyable read. Fans will love this and even if your not a fan, I think you will like it.

good book, interesteing to see the contacts she met so young. well written and easy to follow - but got bored quickly of the 'they screwed us over, he screwed us over, this person screwed ozzy over' blah blah. as for the huge tax bill - HAHA - what goes around - come on your signing tax papers for your dad in your own name - DOH!!!! you realise its wrong but carry on because by the time you're in america you like the lifestyle - deserve to get your arse bitten for it.Opinions aside her and Ozzy love each other so much and it is wonderful to see someone can make someone else that happy - yet in the past they've almost literally killed each other - strange lives some peoplegot the follow on to this so should be interesting...

This was a hard book to read. Sharon's life was a very rough one - a scam artist/mob friendly father; a distant and cold mother; involvement in a shyster music industry; colon cancer surgery and subsequent radiation/chemo therapy; the constant ups and downs of a dysfunctional marriage to an alcoholic/druggie. Whew! At the end of the book, however, things to have somehow worked out for her both personally and in her career. I found myself cheering for her strength and persistence. NOTE: This book is definitely not for a general audience. The language and behaviors will most certainly offend many.

What can I say... I don't have a bad word to say about this book. After reading this book I had nothing but respect and praise for a wonderfully courageous and strong woman. Sharon Osbourne really has been through it all, and has come out of the other side with a passion for life, and a smile on her face. Of course she has done some things that most people would find unacceptable, but thats who she is. She lives life differently to other people. She is painfully honest in this book, and it makes you love her all the more. A fantastic woman.

As an Ozzy fan I read this book out of curiousity...much to my surprise I walked away a fan of Sharon's as well.It's a fabulous roller-coaster ride of rock-n-roll insanity, heartbreaking revelations and shocking truths. It's her story of courage, patience and love. Brutally honest and open, you will alternatedly wonder why Sharon stays with this man and at the same time applaude her loyalty.I laughed out loud, I cried and I was appalled. I highly recommend this book, although not for those faint of heart.I am anxious to read her next book as well.

I specifically bought this book because I wanted to read about Sharon Osbourne's experience with colon cancer. I was disappointed that it was actually a very, very small part of the book, and didn't even come into the story until very near the end. Relatively speaking, it was a very brief account comapared to pages and pages and pages she devoted to other topics in her life. Aside from that, it was an interesting and entertaining read, although it was hard to believe about half the stuff she wrote.

I never read autobiographies but someone left this on our bookshelf at work and I thought I'd give it a go. Being the age that I am, I know more about Sharon's children then I do about her or Ozzy. This left me absolutely amazed by the life that she has lived. I feel that this doesn't paint Ozzy in a very flattering light at all. He was an alcoholic, a drug abuser and prone to beating up his wife but Sharon still seems to paint him as a victim who is totally unaccountable for his actions. This is am entertaining read that shows how Sharon has become as strong as she is.

I like her, it was very readable and of course insightful about the industry and funny too, all that... i don't know why i though she would have more depth to her, it seem like she spent her life being used and abused by the men in it. I feel very sad for her, grr. poor sharon. Had good idea's for her show the managers didn't go for, im sure more of her would have come out there. Anyway, this is nice brain candy to be devoured in a single sitting.

My god, what a life..I was given this book to read on my last holiday, but never got round to reading it. Sharon Osbourne has had a truly crazy life, she should have more faith in herself she is so much a better person than she knows. She should have dumped Ozzy years ago, after everything he put her through, strangling her and mentally and phsically abusing her..wasn't a fan before, but now have more respect for Sharon.

This was an interesting book and although I think Sharon Osbourne is a very strong courageous woman I found it really difficult to constantly read about the abuse she endured being married to Ozzy. One one hand I find it admirable that she stuck by her husband, through thick and thin, through all the drugs and alcohol, on the other hand I feel like she put up with unnecessary abuse. However, in the end you do realize just how much Sharon loves her family and will do anything to protect them.

I actually am a pretty big fan of Sharon Osbourne, but for some reason I just could not get into this book. I think it's because I was hoping it was about her current life, and alot of it is about her childhood and growing up in the music business, which really doesn't interest me at all. I'm going to try and finish it, but it may take a long, long time because there are alot more books out there that I actually want to read.

This was a wild ride of a book. Her life is definitely not conventional. Interesting book but not one I would recommend to many people - language throughout is very strong. But there does seem to be a lot of character strength - she is definitely a take charge person. Her life pre-Ozzie was just as crazy as her life with Ozzie. Talk about dysfunctional!!! Will be interesting to see how the children turn out.

Interesting read, didn't really appreciate all the f words and shatting everywhere, I mean is there any need for this kind of talk, but then that is who she is, alot i didn't realise about where she came from and what made her who she is today...but she stuck to Ozzy through all his alcoholism and drug taking and sleeping around, she sure must love the man, he is lucky that she stuck by him really, he came good in the end though, best thing he did was pack up the drinking by the sounds of it!!

Good God, this woman is a total liability. She's so self-destructive it makes you wonder how she had any success whatsoever. And her and Ozzy together? It's like a volcano fell in love with a tornado. But it's her candid nihilism and total lack of pretentiousness (though not artifice!) that make her lovable and inspiring. Could definitely have done with less of the scatological aspect though.

Brilliant read. She is one hell of an interesting woman. She has been through so much in her life, from money to poverty twice, through a husband who cheated on her numerous times, who used to beat her and tried to kill her, through weight loss and weight gain, and gastric band, cancer, and finally happiness, wealthy, and televisual celebrity. A stunning woman whom I admire for her strength and her courage. She deserves a bloody medal for what she's been through imo!

I have read a few celebrity autobiographies over the years and this is one of the most open and revealing that I have read. A genuine autobiography that is full of true emotion, Sharon has had quite a life and her early years and the volatile relationship with Ozzy make for amazing reading. Love or hate Sharon this book is a fascinating insight into her life. Mrs O is just fabulous - a brilliant read.

Reading this made me think about what I look for in a memoir. I thought I looked for information that would help me live my life. But it turns out it's also fun to read about someone who's completely off the wall. This is a woman who, when angry at her husband, tried to run him down with her car, all the while throwing jewelry out the window. And that's the least of it. Still, she's honest and entertaining.

Sharon Osbourne is the daughter of rock manager Don Arden. She has a very chaotic and wild childhood. She married Ozzy Osbourne of Black Sabbath, but his drinking and drugs almost destroy their marriage. She has three chidlren whom she adores. She started the trend of reality shows, she survived colon cancer, she was a judge on America's Got Talent. But she perseveres and comes back out on top. She is a very funny and outspoken host on the Talk.

I read the British version so I am not sure how it compares to the American version.This is a 'warts and all' telling of her life from childhood to present day. There were times when reading it that my mouth hung open with shock at some of the things she had done and situations she found herself in. I admire her as a business woman and a mom and this book reinforced that.

Insight into Ozzy's "Shaaaaarooooon!" Her very interesting, quite colorful life, in her words. A quick read for me. As I read the book and "saw" in my mind the various stories she was describing on the pages, it felt like an "Osbournes" prequel. No less zany than the television series! She's been through a lot.

I was forced to read this book while traveling! There was nothing else available and I would have been stuck on a plane with nothing but a couple magazines for several hours! I expected to hate it. But the truth is that I read the entire thing and learned more than I ever wanted to know about Ozzy and Sharon. The writing was bad, but at least it passed the time.

Couldn't be a better way to describe this book, "extreme" yes Sharon's life is and was a study in extremes from the extreme way her father treated her, to her extreme life in the music industry, to her extreme marriage to Ozzy and her extreme health problem. Well written book "potty mouth" included, as this seems to match her extreme life.

This is a fairly uncensored book of her life. While there were times, you could tell she was leaving out details; for the most part she was very straight and very honest. The best thing about the autobiography is how she didn't let editors and whatnot change too much of what she said. There is the swearing and the frankness that makes Sharon Sharon.

I am in the generation where the Osbournes on MTV came to life and was fascinated by watching their lives. This book chronicles the early years up to the first season of the Osbournes television show. It is packed full of details about Sharon's life growing up and how she has become the woman she is today.

An excellent read! Nothing is spared in this book, from her love of dogs, problems with her alcoholic and compulsive liar father to the inside dirt on one of the most famous families in music, all from the matriach of the family herself. After reading this book, I have immense respect for Sharon Osbourne, she is one ballsy lady!

Nobody does caustic quite as good as Sharon Osbourne! This is a no holds barred biography about her life with Ozzy and the family, and she gets the boot into everyone that has ever crossed her. This is the type of celebrity biography that I like to read-dirt getting dished, controversial topics, enemy bashing...a really entertaining read.

This book was Fabulous!! I loved it!! Sharon is so funny and a great writter, I learnt a lot about her family and the great Ozzy. Although she has gone through some hard times, real hard times but she has handled it like Sharon would. I wont give too much away but I would say if you are interested in her and her family this is a great read. Never a dull moment in this house!

I have a deeper appreciation for Sharon and her devotion to her husband and family. Even through all the bad times, bad tempers, and drunkenness she stuck through and fought to the end. I will be more inspired to stick things out when the going gets tough after reading this; seeing that I thought I had it bad when having to deal with alcoholic family members.

I really liked this book. I really enjoyed reading about Sharon's early life and how she grew up. I can't believe her family has treated her so horribly. Sharon talks about some of the same things as was in Ozzy's own bio, but Sharon had totally different perspective on things. Throughout the whole book she was funny, smart, and man I wouldn't want to be on her bad side :-)Very interesting.

I loved every page! She's always been a heroine of mine and that admiration only grew stronger understanding the details of her trials and triumphs. I recommend this book to anyone but specifically for women like me who've made their career in the entertainment industry, she's rock star royalty! Looking forward to the next few...

A facinating read on the inner workings of the music world. If you can ignore F* on every page, then go for it. I was totally intrigued by the life this woman has lead. Anyone interested in the music industry should check this one out!

This lady is the best whippersnapper around. She has a great outlook on life and boy did she have a tough one. She is wonderful. This book is not boring and who doesn't like to read about someone else's life?

Very entertaining book. Sharon writes just like she speaks, with lots of curse words! Makes for a very interesting read. Her life is amazing; she has gone through so much. Makes me feel good about the little problems I have! Totally recommend this book.

What I learned is that Sharon called the kettle black.:) Ozzy was married and she did not want to let go.Even though I am not a fan of her I did enjoy reading this book very much.It is interesting to hear more about the music world back in the days.

One of the craziest stories I've read. If you interested by bizarre people in crazy situations, this is for you. Lots of swearing, but fascinating look into Sharon's chaotic childhood and weirdly romantic marriage to Ozzy and their countless near-death experiences.

I read this and laughed my whole way through it. In places it is sad and you are rooting for her to get through it. Overall it is a good, lite read. It will show you a whole other side of the family that even the tv didn't really show.

I loved Sharon's description of her totally unconventional upbringing. She loves her family fiercly which is amazing. There were moments in the book where I laughed out loud. Some of the moments were so outrageous. It was like a guilty pleasure.

This is perhaps one of the most difficult books I have ever begun, not because it is boring or poorly written, quite the opposite, but I have read longer books in shorter amounts of time, I haven't read anything particularly challenging recently, so my reading may be getting slow.

I wasn't expecting this book to be as good as it turned out to be. I always thought of her as a spoiled rockstars wife, she has put up with so much crap. Awesome book with lots of in depth information that most celebs would keep hidden.

After listening to this on audio CD I started trying to talk like Sharon (inadvertently of course). This was a great audio CD...it made me look forward to going to work so I could listen to her talk about her crazy up bringing/current life.

Interesting. Sharon's father was a music manager and that is how she met Ozzie, as her father was managing his band. They seem to have had a crazy relationship as Ozzie was on the road, cheating and drinking. Lots of drama in Sharon's life with her relationship with Ozzie and her father.

I have always been fascinated by Sharon Osbourne and wondered how she ended up with Ozzy. I am almost done with the book and can't say I understand why she is still with him but it makes a little bit more sense knowing her background.

Really interesting book about a strong woman and her relationships primarily with her Dad and Ozzy. Couldn't believe some of the stuff she's been through and put up with. I normally don't read autobiographies but I couldn't put this down!

I had a lot of different thoughts about this book. Part of me really liked it, it was honest, candid, absurd, crazy. The other part was saddened by what Sharon has endured throughout her childhood, and relationships. Extreme really does describe it all, the ups and downs.

A fantastic read. So interesting and warm. I wouldn't say I've ever been a fan of the Osbournes but I was given this book as a present and I have loved it and I see the family in a different light now! I would really like to read her next one. I would recommend this to anybody.

facinating read. Sharon is an amazing woman and this comes through on each and every page! The book follows a very strict chronological orderand this helps to emphasise how her life evolved andhow her success(s) are a result of very hard work...andabsolute fearlessness!!

I gave it 5 stars because it was such a good read! I was captivated and couldn't put it down. She has led such a wild life. I find it odd though that she & Ozzy have s#!% on a lot of things. I would never ever even consider doing that. Is it a UK thing? Hmm

I only got 3/4 into this before I lost my place and never went back to it- I will one day though, I promise. From what I did read, it was really good- her childhood is portrayed beautifully and she is very honest. It does help she always was my favorite X factor judge as well ;)

If your life feels like it's falling apart, buy this book and read it and realize that nothing can or should be taken seriously and know that life is wonderful because Sharon Osbourne is in this world.

I found that I really like Sharon Osbourne. I was somewhat put off by what he allowed in her life and felt at times she condoned it, but it is also a frame of mind I've seen often working in law enforcement. It was a bit crass, but it is her story and she told it her way.

Was interesting enough. Not written very well though, felt like it was dictated by Sharon. Amazed that she put up with such abuse, physical and mental but look at the example her parents gave her as a her reference point. Certainly paints a picture of a pathetic Ozzy who is not capable of much.

Say what now!?! That pretty much sums it up!! One very crazy ride splattered with even crazier antics throughout! Read it if you are questioning your own family's sanity! You will happily reveal the normalcy of your extremely boring and relatively sane relatives!lol
I really respect Sharon, I understand what it's like to be the wife of a wild man! Fun to read

I afire Sharon and her complete honesty in writing about her life
In a word WOW what a woman she is!!
Fascinating. Didn't realize how much crap she went through with her father, and with Ozzie.
I realy though this would have been a good book. Was so dissapointed. Not bad but not good. Not really worth the while to read there are many other books to read rather than this one.

I found this book to be inspirational...Sharon showed me that all could be overcome!!!
shocking, rude, unreasonable and very loud, but always loving, funny and true! I love Sharon and the whole Osbourne clan, so me this was a fascinating read

Without a doubt, she is an amazing woman and I admire her strength and tell-it-how-it-is attitude. She leads an interesting life. But I didn't actually finish this book.

Sharon writes like she talks! A good book looking into her and Ozzy Osbourne's life.
Loved it... she's had an amazing life and parts made me laugh out loud to my husbands amusement and some made me sad and weepy good read!

Such a great book, I couldn't put it down!

I wouldn't give it two hoots about Sharon Osbourne, but just because her dad managed Black Sabbath and she is Ozzy Osbourne's wife I decided to give her a go and pick her autobiography. After all, any insights into the Sabbs and their line up can't hurt! Well, what's there to get?There are some nice glimpses at the music business of the 50s and 60s, when rock n' roll hit Britain and her dad, Don Arden, once described as the 'Al Capone of music', used to manage some of the then big names. It's nice; but since she had a nasty feud with her father it quickly turn revengeful, a family vendetta where her dad is all but spared. Don Arden was indeed a big name, and so getting to see his disgusting scams and how he ripped even his own bands (ELO...) is here quite a take on the music industry back then:'... he was just one among many. The business was full of lying, cheating mobsters. There was barely a decent person among them. Everywhere I turned there was another liar, another bullshitter, another fake.'There are whole chapters, too, dedicated to her husband Ozzy. How she picked him up after he was thrown out of Black Sabbath; how she launched his solo career; the tragedy that unfolded (the death of Randy Rhoads...); how she tried and have him to get clean and sober; the creation of the Ozzfest… There's no denying she's a tough, tenacious woman, and a determined manager who knows what she wants and usually gets it! Thing is, since she's Ozzy's wife it quickly turn into an insight into their marriage, and the whole becomes an unsettling tale of a toxic relationship. She wasn't a saint for sure (agressive, arrogant, violent) but the recounting of all the abuses, physical and emotional, melted upon her is frankly harrowing to read. Ozzy has a reputation for being clownish, wait to see how he was behind closed doors...Now, yes, she's a self-centred 'motormouth' and in between the lines you see all the shallowness and insecurities of the celebrity culture she belongs to: the craving for fame, money flouting, names dropping... I found it all, not annoying, but quite pitiful. She can also sound funnily hypocrite, as when she offers her opinion on nowadays music industry:'... full of small, blinkered persons. There are few pioneers..., people prepared to take a chance... the majority are pampered, untalented also-rans who have no musical ability at all. I don't even know an A&R man these days who can play an instrument or read or write music. All they have is an ear for what is current.'This coming from someone who paid her debts by being some judge on some sh%tty talent show, it's quite gutted!Having said that, she can attract sympathy and some sort of admiration too. She's coming from a dysfunctional family and, sadly, ends up living in a dysfunctional marriage herself (although she's absolutely head over heels about Ozzy! Her love just shines throughout...). She is selfless to the point of coping with Ozzy's behaviours, even if for the sake of her kids (sadly, ain't it always like that with abused women?). She is also very strong, as her battle against cancer shows quite clearly. She has, in a word, the tenacity of an indestructible warrior - there's no taking that away from her.A loose canon ball with a attitude, Sharon Osbourne surely is not everyone's cup of tea. Well, as a shallow celebrity she certainly is not mine; not matter how admirable her determination! But I picked this up to get insight into the music, and when it comes to that her side of the story makes for a great read. From the rock n' roll era to the Ozzfest, straight through Black Sabbath and Ozzy Osbourne (I personally don't care about The X doolali) here's a frank insight into it all. Like her or not: her impact remains.

What an eye opener! Extreme is the perfect title as Sharon takes us through her life with a manipulative, angry, abusive father, a loveless mother and a tumultuous life of highs and lows. Her love for Ozzy is evident. The abuse is mutual, a result of difficult upbringing, and having been taught that violence is the norm. Home life and life on the road are purely absurd. The Osbourne's infatuation with peeing, and defecating is a bit off-putting, if not downright disturbing.  This autobiography is raw and real. It brings the reader on a journey through the business of music on the road, from the filth to the joy. You can feel yourself next to Sharon just off the stage feeling joy, pride and love for her husband, except for the times she feels fear and disgust for that same man. This is life. It is in its most extreme form, but it is real. It is authentic. It made me feel compassion, worry, hope and love. It intrigued me to search the videos of Ozzy, Black Sabbath and Kelly's music, as well as Leno and Letterman interviews, ranging from Ozzy with tremors and seemingly incoherent, to interviews with a year sober, looking fantastic and showing his loveliness, and wittiness that has continued to charm Sharon over the years. Sharon, you are lovely, warm, witty and real. Thank you for sharing your story.

Anyone interested in Rock 'N Roll history needs to read this. This book is invigorating and inspiring and entertaining in a voyeuristic and cathartic way. If you expect the story of a rock 'n roll princess you will be surprised not to find that but instead, the story of someone very gifted, who perseveres and triumphs and adapts to find incredible strength scrambling out of the world of quicksand celebrity. She tells the truth and the truth is more valuable than anything. I can now see how this woman can be so vibrant and has experienced so much. She is a great role model for someone like me. A gifted business woman and orchestrator, I can learn so much from her. She wears resilience like chain mail but beneath that she completely understands the unconditional nature of love and kindness. Of all the people I would want cloned this is the one person that should be because everybody needs a Sharon in their life. This book was fantastic and I want to hear more from her.

I have read this for my 2020 reading challenge prompt “genre you don’t normally care for” and for that’s autobiographies. A work colleague lent me this book so it also ticks off the “borrowed from a friend book”. I was determined to read this as I like Sharon Osbourne and I felt that if I was going to read a genre I don’t normally read I want it to be someone I like. First thoughts are you can not make this sh** up, I felt like I was reading fiction, talk about Sharon’s dad being a wannabe mafia man. I felt that the first 12 chapters or were very business oriented and not about Sharon’s personal and private life, at stages I felt that it very name dropping and show offy.I felt that the second half of her book from about the cancer onwards was much more Sharon Osbourne and the Sharon we have come to know, it was more personal than the first half.

This book has probably been on my shelf about 12 years, pretty sure I was given it for Christmas 2005 and I've always bypassed it when looking for something new to read, until now. Very pleased I have finally read it, well-written account of Sharon & Ozzy's career/life; which I knew little about. The final chapters on the X Factor and the Osbournes felt a little rushed, but perhaps that was due to the fact that when this was published, only one series of the X Factor had been made. I'd happily read other books written by Sharon.

There were parts of this book I understood. There were parts of this book that made me angry. For both Sharon and the society she grew up in. Along with the one she married into. It was a hard read but what a good biography does is give you insight into a persons life. Peals back things a little more. Some parts were questionable, but I still found it fascinating as a whole and anytime you look at someone or something with rose colored glasses just remember nothing is what it seems. Especially Sharon Osborne.

This was my first ever autobiography I’ve read. And it was a great experience. I was introduced to Black Sabbath, Led Zeppelin and Deep Purple when I was a teenager when most of my peers only listened to boy bands. It was great to see the story from a female perspective who experienced these amazing but also difficult and strange times. Sharon’s life definitely deserves a story and it was very entertaining and a pleasure to read. Shocking sometimes (extreme is a very good title here). I loved it.

#9 on list of "100 BOOKS TO READ BEFORE YOU DIE" was "THE ROAD" by CORMAC McCARTHY. I read this book while listening to the audible version narrated by TOM STECHSCHULTE . This was also an OPRAH'S BOOK-CLUB pick. This post-apocalyptic novel was excellent. The relationship between a father and his son trying to survive in what is left of a violent and grotesque world is very moving. I watched the movie after reading this and it was done well, but this book is a must-read!

BEST AUTOBIOGRAPHY EVER!!I can't believe it took me so long to find this book and read it. Nothing about Sharon's life is off limits and she goes into every detail, which is mostly very painful. I had no idea what she'd endured. This woman deserves every ounce of success she has earned during her lifetime and marriage to Ozzy. I don't think he'd still be alive without her. Love you Sharon!

I listened to this book, so it definitely went by very quickly. I enjoyed hearing the stories directly from Sharon herself, and I learned a lot about her early life/career with her dad. However, having watched The Osbournes on MTV and later her talk show, most of the later part of the book had very few surprises. It was still a decent and quick read though.

Can’t say I enjoyed this but i guess it’s probably a fairly accurate description of her life. The writing is terrible and so much of it is vacuous nonsense. They’re just not very interesting people. Sure there are some crazy stories in here and some insight into the dark underbelly of the entertainment industry but I certainly won’t be reading anything else by her

This was amazing. I never knew Sharon had gone through so much. You hear about the stories in the press but to hear it from the horses mouth, her dad was awful to her, Ozzy to at times. She is so strong and honest and brave.This has made me see Sharon in a whole new light. Give this a go. At the end I cried, because it was a audiobook and she started welling up so did I. 💓💓

I’ll give this one a 3.4. I love memoirs and I especially love when the author lays it all out on table. Sharon revealed so many things that I never knew about her upbringing and Ozzy. Who knew she was so crazy? She let the readers in on some behind the scenes truth of some of the stories and rumors that were in the media and as always, there is two sides to every story.

Very interesting read.Not a fan of The Osbourne's or Ozzy but I thoroughly enjoyed learning about Sharon, her early life, and life with Ozzy.I am full of admiration of this woman after reading this book!
Absoulty loved this book. Her books are hilarious reads and I can't put them down. Easy reads
Its not possible to not get a lot of respect for this woman.
She’s a patient woman...

Very interesting insight into the music business, and the Osbourne Family at large
Such a good read, I only wished it was longer! I love her voice

Man this was really such a good book. Really glad I got the chance to read it.

A moving account of her life with her violent shady family, especially her father then her life with Ozzy and her family up until April 2004.So much I just didn't know.
Hugely insightful peek into their lives at the time. Lots of stuff about their early relationships and struggles.
Loved the book!Thanks for the honesty and the realism of your lives. I truly enjoyed reading this story. I highly recommend it.
I liked her straight forward way of telling about her life. No excuses, just matter of fact. I don't usually like biographical books, but maybe I've just been reading the wrong ones.
Dont usually read biographies but this was a secret santa present. Took me 3 days I could not put it down

Sounds about right. A story of Privilage.
“It’s not giving up; it’s that there are times when it’s right to move on.” - Sharon Osbourne

I read "SHARON OSBOURNE EXTREME: MY AUTOBIOGRAPHY" by SHARON OSBOURNE while also listening to the Audible version by SHARON OSBOURNE. Sharon's life with Ozzy Osbourne was very interesting. Sharon reveals the truth behind the headlines in a frank, intimate, and articulate way.

The Osbournes are notoriously good at rewriting history, so I suggest reading a number of books about their history, if you want a truer picture. For example, Rudy Sarzo and Bob Daisley’s books, while not as well written, are more believable as those two musicians kept their own personal journals and have less questionable ulterior motives when presenting a historical perspective.
Really good read had a very hard life and self made women

I read this book years ago when it first came out. It's a no holes barred account of her early years. Sharon is not afraid to tell it like it was, and it was quite shocking in places.It's an interesting read whether you like her or not.

I have wanted to read this book for a LONG time! Obviously, I finally did and found it pretty fascinating. Sharon is who she is and doesn't apologize for it. Though I could have never persevered and came out the other side like she did with her circumstances in her life, she brings a very optimistic resolution to her choices she has made to her readers. This is a great book with outrageous stories, and really a book about fighting for love and getting back up again, and again, and again, when you are knocked down.

Im not a fan of biographies but i wanted to love this so much as i am a Sharon fan, she has such a awesome personality. But i couldnt really get into this book but i think its me rather than the book. I just dont enjoy biographies on the whole.

This book was really disappointingAfter reading Ozzy's memoir I thought I would get a really clear look at the woman behind him. Ozzy was so open about how badly he treated Sharon and I really wanted the insights about her experience.
AmazingWhat an incredible story Sharon has to tell, and she has told it so well. I highly recommend this book to those that want to be informed, entertained, and inspired.Bravo Mrs. O!

I never really.knew how Sharon stayed with Ozzy after everything I've heard but after reading just the first few chapters it is.clear that dispite her appeal of being the "stable" one she has loved a life. of.abuse by people who have also been abused the the cycle carried on.
